title: Madhubani, Kalighat, and Kalamkari Art - Multiple Choice Questions
subtitle: NIOS Class 12 Painting - Traditional Indian Folk and Craft Painting Styles

questions.question: What is another name for Madhubani painting?
questions.explanation: Madhubani paintings are also called Mithila paintings. This genre of painting originated in the Madhubani district of the Mithila region in Bihar.

questions.question: Where did Madhubani painting originate?
options: Madhubani district of the Mithila region in Bihar
questions.explanation: Madhubani painting originated in the Madhubani district of the Mithila region in Bihar.

questions.question: What is a Kohbar in Madhubani tradition?
questions.explanation: Kohbar is the bridal chamber. Traditionally, Madhubani paintings were made by women on the mud wall of the Kohbar.

questions.question: What was the traditional theme of Madhubani paintings?
questions.explanation: Traditionally, Madhubani paintings' theme was Hindu mythology and local beliefs, painted to orient newlyweds to matrimony and fertility.

questions.question: What is the purpose of Kohbar paintings?
options: Orienting the newlyweds to matrimony and fertility
questions.explanation: Madhubani paintings on the Kohbar wall were painted with the aim of orienting the newlyweds to matrimony and fertility.

questions.question: Who always paints the Kohbar fresco?
questions.explanation: The Kohbar fresco is always painted by married women, who sing ritual wedding songs while preparing and painting.

questions.question: What is the Kohbar in the groom's in-law's home?
options: The groom's designated room where newlyweds conduct religious rituals
questions.explanation: Before he departs from his in-law's home after the wedding ceremony, the Kohbar is the groom's designated room in the bride's home in which the newlyweds conduct religious rituals.

questions.question: How is the base prepared for Kohbar painting?
options: By painting the desired portion of wall with rice slurry
questions.explanation: Married women prepare the base by painting the desired portion of the wall with rice slurry while singing ritual wedding songs.

questions.question: What is used to draw figures initially in Madhubani painting?
options: Charcoal or a thin strip of bamboo dipped in lamp soot
questions.explanation: The figures are drawn with charcoal, or a thin strip of bamboo dipped in lamp soot.

questions.question: How is the bamboo strip turned into a brush for Madhubani painting?
options: By rolling some cotton wool on one end
questions.explanation: The bamboo strip is turned into a brush by rolling some cotton wool on one end, and vibrant colours are applied as desired.

questions.question: What creates black color in traditional Madhubani painting?
options: Lamp soot or burnt heads of Sorghum or Jowar
questions.explanation: Black colour was made from lamp soot or burnt heads of Sorghum or Jowar (a grain crop).

questions.question: How is yellow color traditionally made in Madhubani painting?
options: From turmeric or sap of banyan tree mixed with lime
questions.explanation: Yellow colour was made from turmeric or sap of banyan tree mixed with lime.

questions.question: What creates saffron color in Madhubani painting?
questions.explanation: Saffron colour was made from Palash blossoms (flame of the forest flowers).

questions.question: What is the source of red color in traditional Madhubani painting?
questions.explanation: Red colour was made from Kusum blossoms.

questions.question: What creates dull green color in Madhubani painting?
questions.explanation: Dull green colour was made from cowdung, showing the use of readily available natural materials.

questions.question: How is crimson color made in Madhubani painting?
questions.explanation: Crimson colour was made from Peepul bark (the sacred fig tree).

questions.question: What creates blue color in traditional Madhubani painting?
questions.explanation: Blue colour was made from ink or indigo, a natural plant-based dye.

questions.question: How is deep pink color created in Madhubani painting?
questions.explanation: Deep pink colour was made from Mahavar, a traditional cosmetic powder.

questions.question: What symbols are included in a Kohbar fresco?
options: Fertility symbols, deities, and auspicious symbols like moon, sun, tulsi, parrot, peacock, fish, cobra, sparrow, tortoise, lily vine, clove tree, bamboo, betel vine, water pitcher
questions.explanation: A Kohbar fresco has fertility symbols, figures of deities and local characters like Naina Jogin, and many auspicious symbols including moon, sun, tulsi plant, parrot, peacock, fish, cobra, sparrow, tortoise, lily vine, clove tree, bamboo plant, betel vine, water pitcher etc.

questions.question: What is characteristic about space in Madhubani frescoes?
options: There are no empty spaces - gaps are covered with geometrical and floral motifs, animal and bird figures
questions.explanation: There are no empty spaces in a Madhubani fresco - the gaps are covered with geometrical and floral motifs, animal and bird figures.

questions.question: Who is Naina Jogin in Madhubani painting?
options: A local character depicted in Kohbar frescoes
questions.explanation: Naina Jogin is a local character depicted in Kohbar frescoes along with deities and fertility symbols.

questions.question: Who created the famous Kohbar Ghar painting in the Crafts Museum collection?
questions.explanation: The famous 'Kohbar Ghar' painting was created by Padmashree Ganga Devi and is in the collection of Crafts Museum, New Delhi.

questions.question: What themes do modern Madhubani artists experiment with?
options: Secular themes, rendering paintings on fabric, canvas, board and paper
questions.explanation: To cater to a growing urban market, nowadays artists are experimenting with secular themes and rendering the paintings on fabric, canvas, board and paper.

questions.question: Where is Kalighat painting named after?
options: Kalighat in Kolkata, where the famous Kali temple is located
questions.explanation: This style of painting is named after the place it originated and developed in - Kalighat in Kolkata, where the famous Kali temple attracts millions of pilgrims from all over India.

questions.question: What period's social and cultural turmoil do Kalighat paintings document?
questions.explanation: Kalighat paintings culminate and archive the social and cultural turmoil in 19th-century Kolkata.

questions.question: Who were the Patuas?
options: Traditional painters of scrolls and toys who migrated to Kolkata
questions.explanation: The traditional Patuas, painters of scrolls and toys, had migrated to the city from rural areas of Bengal in large numbers and began creating Kalighat paintings.

questions.question: Who were the traditional buyers of Kalighat paintings?
options: Visiting pilgrims who carried them home as souvenirs
questions.explanation: Patuas began to paint individual panels for sale to the visiting pilgrims who carried them home as souvenirs of their visit to the Kali temple in Kolkata.

questions.question: Why were Kalighat paintings made on paper in watercolor?
options: To keep the costs low for pilgrims
questions.explanation: To keep the costs low so pilgrims could afford them, the paintings were painted on paper in watercolour with bold lines and simplified figures.

questions.question: What characterized the style of early Kalighat paintings?
options: Bold lines and colours with simplified figures
questions.explanation: To keep costs low, the lines and colours were bold, and the figures simplified, creating a distinctive style.

questions.question: What secular subjects did Kalighat painters begin to depict?
options: Local scandals, current proverbs, current events, nautch girls, musicians, everyday scenes
questions.explanation: Gradually Kalighat painters began to depict local scandals, current proverbs, and current events. Subjects included the nautch girl, the musician, the woman combing her hair, the chubby woman holding a red rose, the snake, the cat, the crayfish, etc.

questions.question: What material was used for later, finer Kalighat paintings?
questions.explanation: Later, Kalighat paintings were made on fine-quality hemp paper depicting Hindu Gods and Goddesses in garish colours.

questions.question: What international recognition did Kalighat paintings receive?
options: Their popularity in Europe led to lithographs being made in Germany
questions.explanation: The popularity of Kalighat paintings in Europe led to lithographs of them being made in Germany.

questions.question: Who keeps the Kalighat style alive today?
options: Patuas who make copies of famous old Kalighat paintings
questions.explanation: The style is kept alive by patuas who make copies of famous old Kalighat paintings for a living.

questions.question: What story does the Kalighat painting 'Sita with Luv-Kush' depict?
options: Sita with her two sons, telling them a story from the Ramayana
questions.explanation: The subject is taken from the Ramayana. It shows Sita with her two sons Luv and Kush, sitting on a rock under a tree. Sita is telling her sons a story and they listen spellbound.

questions.question: What is accorded primacy in Kalighat painting tradition?
questions.explanation: In accordance with the Kalighat tradition, drawing has been accorded primacy, with human bodies depicted with clarity.

questions.question: How are curves highlighted in Kalighat paintings?
options: With light and shade effects close to the outlines of curves
questions.explanation: The curves of the female form have been highlighted with light and shade effects close to the outlines of the curves.

questions.question: What are hallmark features of traditional Kalighat paintings?
questions.explanation: The hallmark elongated eyes and soft faces mark the work as an authentic traditional Kalighat painting.

questions.question: What does the word Kalamkari mean?
options: Craft of the pen (from Persian Qalamkari)
questions.explanation: The word Kalamkari is derived from Persian Qalamkari, which means the craft of the pen.

questions.question: What is Kalamkari?
options: A craft style using pen and colours to paint figures on fabric
questions.explanation: Kalamkari is a craft style which uses pen and colours to paint figures on fabric. Sometimes it combines pen drawing and block printing.

questions.question: Where is Kalamkari mostly practised?
options: Andhra Pradesh and Telangana in southern states
questions.explanation: Kalamkari is mostly practised in the southern states of Andhra Pradesh and Telangana, though earlier the style was practised in other areas as well.

questions.question: Under whose patronage did Kalamkari reach its zenith?
questions.explanation: Under the patronage of the Mughal rulers, the craft of Kalamkari reached its zenith, and kalamkari textiles were exported to many Asian and European countries.

questions.question: When did Kalamkari constitute a large chunk of India's textile trade?
questions.explanation: Historical documents tell that around the 18th century, Kalamkari fabrics constituted a large chunk of India's textile trade with Persia and the countries of the Middle East.

questions.question: What are the two major centers of Kalamkari production?
questions.explanation: Srikalahasti and Machilipatanam developed as key centers of Kalamkari production, possibly because Coromandel and Pulikat on the eastern coast were major textile export centers.

questions.question: What is the theme of Srikalahasti style Kalamkari?
questions.explanation: The Srikalahasti style of Kalamkari developed around a temple town and was patronized by temples, so its theme is Hindu mythology.

questions.question: What technique does Srikalahasti Kalamkari use?
options: Only the 'Kalam' or pen for free-hand drawing and filling colours
questions.explanation: In Srikalahasti style, only the 'Kalam' or pen is used for a free-hand drawing of the subject and filling in the colours.

questions.question: What technique does Machilipatanam Kalamkari use?
options: A mix of pen work and block printing
questions.explanation: The Machilipatanam style developed under Mughal patronage and is a mix of pen work and block printing.

questions.question: What motifs does Machilipatanam Kalamkari favor?
options: Ornate arch, flowers, animal figures, tree of life
questions.explanation: To cater to the demand of its Mughal patrons, Machilipatnam style favoured the use of motifs like the ornate arch, flowers, animal figures, and tree of life.

questions.question: What products did Machilipatanam produce for Asian markets?
questions.explanation: Machilipatnam produced namaz-mats (prayer mats), tents, and curtains for its largely Asian markets.

questions.question: What did Machilipatanam produce for European markets?
questions.explanation: For the European market, Machilipatanam produced bedsheets and quilt covers.

questions.question: What is the Kalam in Kalamkari?
options: The reed pen prepared by sharpening one end of an 8-inch stick with wool/felt rolled in middle
questions.explanation: Kalam, or the reed pen is prepared by sharpening one end of an 8-inch long stick of reed or palm. On the middle of the stick, a bit of wool or felt is rolled. This absorbs the colour, and slight pressure on this roll allows colour to flow onto the fabric.
